Award.AwardTitle: RAPID: Measuring Information Consumption and Beliefs During the Covid-19 Pandemic.

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration: In recent months, the global COVID-19 pandemic has been accompanied by a surge in pandemic-related false information, exposing shortcomings in the diffusion of high quality information through online networks and in our understanding of who is most susceptible to false and misleading information during times of crisis. Important questions remain about who is able to discriminate low-quality information from high-quality information related to COVID-19 and who is most vulnerable to low-quality information during the pandemic. This project investigates susceptibility to false and misleading information both in the time of, and related to, the COVID-19 pandemic. As government agencies, civic organizations, and for-profit companies work together to combat coronavirus-related false information, an understanding of who is most likely to believe false information — and mistrust true information — is necessary for crafting and distributing targeted public health communications. <br/><br/>Social and behavioral literature offer competing insights into how the current epidemic might impact people’s ability to evaluate the veracity of information. This project will test a series of theoretically informed hypotheses about why we might expect people’s ability to correctly identify the veracity of information to change in the time of COVID-19, and why we might expect people’s ability to discern the veracity of COVID-19 related information to differ from their ability to ascertain the veracity of non-Covid-19 related information. By sourcing real time news articles to crowds of ordinary citizens as well as professional fact checkers over a multi-month period, this project will investigate the individual-level determinants of susceptibility to false information in real time, whether ordinary citizens can be employed to crowdsource the labeling of high- and low-quality information, and whether crowdsourced fact-checking can reduce the prevalence of false information in the information ecosystem.<br/><br/>This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project examined susceptibility to false and misleading news about the Covid-19 pandemic in the first month(s) and year of the pandemic; it also assessed people’s ability to identify the veracity of news generally as a baseline for comparison. Previous research offers competing insights into how the pandemic might impact vulnerability to misinformation, and we sought to test theoretically-motivated hypotheses about people’s ability to identify the veracity of news during this period. 


Our data collection, which asked both survey respondents and professional fact checkers to evaluate popular news articles within 72 hours of publication, was broken into two studies. For Study 1, which ran over 8 days in May and June 2020, we sourced 10 articles twice a week for four weeks (a total of 40 articles assessed by 90 respondents each). For Study 2, which ran once a week from July 2020 through January 2021, we sourced 10 articles per week (a total of 420 articles assessed by 90 respondents each). In both studies, the 10 articles were split between five “normal” news articles (using the article selection mechanism from our previous study) and five Covid-19-related articles (using a dictionary-based method to determine that the article covered the pandemic). Each article was also assessed by a panel of six fact-checkers, the evaluations of which were used to determine an article’s veracity. Taken together, we were able to assess the extent to which respondents believed false articles in near real-time, as well as the individual characteristics that were associated with belief.  


Our project has thus far yielded five significant insights. First, we found that levels of belief in false news remained high in the early months of the pandemic. Moreover, there was practically no difference in the levels of belief in false news stories related to Covid-19 and the difference in belief in false news stories generally, despite the life-and-death nature of the former. 


Second, ideological congruence (i.e. the alignment of the ideology of a respondent and of a news article) and familiarity with the false story were most strongly associated with belief in false news, both for Covid-19 related and general false news stories.


Third, we find that increased age is associated with a lower likelihood of believing false news. This finding suggests that sharing false news, which has been shown to have been positively associated with age, is not necessarily linked to belief in false news, introducing compelling future lines of research. We also found that respondents with higher levels of reported income were less likely to believe general misinformation relative to those with lower income; however, the opposite is true for misinformation about the pandemic. 


Fourth, we tested the effect of asking respondents to search online for additional information when evaluating false news articles. Paradoxically (and alarmingly), we found that the act of online search in real-time increased belief in false news. We collected Google search results, using a custom-built browser plug-in, around these articles and show that this effect is primarily driven by search results that return other low-quality sources that corroborate the original false story. This provides compelling empirical evidence for data voids — false news publishers push online users into information spaces where there may be little credible news but plenty of other low-quality news sources. Importantly, this finding runs counter to interventions suggested by many media literacy programs, namely that users should search for additional information online to evaluate news veracity.


And finally, this project introduced a transparent and replicable study design that can support future research. Previous studies on belief in misinformation generally used outdated articles selected by the researchers themselves, which does not reflect how people encounter online information ‘in the wild.’ Our design more closely mirrored the real online environment, as well as enabled us to collect data in real-time about rapidly changing information as the pandemic developed. 


Future analyses of data from this project will explore who believes and disbelieves true news around COVID, the impact of local case counts on belief in false news, and the relationship between belief in false news and self-reported health behaviors. 


As government agencies, civic organizations, and for-profit companies work together to combat coronavirus-related misinformation, an understanding of who is most likely to believe false news (and mistrust true news) is necessary for crafting and distributing targeted public health communications. We identified both levels of, and characteristics associated with, belief in false news, enabling key stakeholders to develop evidence-based strategies aimed at protecting communities against misinformation. We also tested a popular intervention — using online search to evaluate the veracity of news — and showed that it risks the possibility of misinforming more people. This finding can help inform decisions by search engines displaying news about potentially harmful topics, as well as civic organizations creating media and digital literacy guides.
